image.altText: A man in a black T-shirt holds signs saying "Trump is a traitor" and "Fani Willis will bring Trump down"

items.synopsis: The 45th US president is formally charged on 13 counts by authorities in Georgia over alleged interference in the state's 2020 election results. Follow live.

title.children: Georgia books Trump on 13 charges including violation of oath and conspiracy to commit forgery

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Trump is speaking to the media on the tarmac. "I believe it is a very sad day for America which should never happen," he says. He stresses he has "done nothing wrong".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump is addressing media from the airport after leaving Fulton County Jail

children.content: Trump is speaking to the media on the tarmac.
"I believe it is a very sad day for America which should never happen," he says.
He stresses he has "done nothing wrong".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Trump's motorcade has arrived back at the airport. It is currently on the tarmac by Trump Force One. He arrived just after 8pm local time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump arrives back at Atlanta airport

children.content: Trump's motorcade has arrived back at the airport.
It is currently on the tarmac by Trump Force One.
He arrived just after 8pm local time.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the motorcade rolls back towards Atlanta airport jail records confirm Donald Trump has been booked on 13 charges. The charges are: Violation of Georgia Rico (Racketeer Influenced And Corrupt Organisations) Solicitation of Violation of Oath by Public Officer Conspiracy to Commit Impersonating a Public Officer Conspiracy to Commit Forgery in the First Degree Conspiracy to Commit False Statements and Writings Conspiracy to Commit Filing False Documents Conspiracy to Commit Forgery in the First Degree Conspiracy to Commit False Statements and Writings Filing False Documents Solicitation of Violation of Oath by Public Officer False Statements and Writings Solicitation of Violation of Oath by Public Officer False Statements and Writings There are more than one charge for some of the types of offences. The records put his height at 6’3” (1.92m) and his weight at 215lbs (97.5kg). The former US president’s hair colour, if you were wondering, is described as "blond or strawberry".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump has been booked

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a suit and red tie gives a thumbs up as he walks down the steps next to an airplane

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump hands himself in to authorities in Fulton County, Atlanta, to be arrested over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the state's 2020 election results.

title.children: Donald Trump hands himself in over Georgia election indictment

image.altText: Dassi Erlich, Nicole Meyer and Elly Sapper

items.synopsis: Leifer was sentenced to 15 years in jail for 18 sexual offences against Elly Sapper and Dassi Erlich while serving as their school principal.

title.children: The sisters at the centre of the Malka Leifer case react to their former principal's jail sentence

image.altText: Crash

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin offers his condolences after a plane crash that authorities say killed Wagner Group chief Yevgeny Prigozhin.

title.children: Putin breaks silence after plane crash that Russia says killed Prigozhin

image.altText: A woman holding a pride flag at a rally.

items.synopsis: Transgender people are stuck on waiting lists for years and spending tens of thousands of dollars to access gender-affirming surgery, but now an application has been made to list the procedures as specific Medicare items.

title.children: Trans Australians waiting years for gender-affirming surgery, as Medicare bid looms

image.altText: A room with gaming tables and a bar.

items.synopsis: Police arrest 21 people in a raid on an illegal casino operating in a factory in Truganina, in Melbourne's west.

title.children: Police raid illegal casino operating in Melbourne's west

image.altText: A close-up of a penguin chick

items.synopsis: Thousands of baby emperor penguins drowned last year in Antarctica as sea ice broke up early and reached record lows, British researchers say, reinforcing dire predictions about the future survival of the species.

title.children: Scientists say thousands of baby emperor penguins drowned or froze to death last year. Here's why

image.altText: The polluted air captured in the Monas monument in Jakarta on 11 August 2023.

items.synopsis: Jakarta residents dealing with some of the worst air quality in the world are told to wear masks and work from home, with some contemplating moving to Bali.

title.children: As Jakarta's air quality gets worse, residents consider moving to Bali where the pollution is only moderate

image.altText: A group of school children eat sandwiches near a park.

items.synopsis: Public health researchers are concerned rising cost of living pressures are opening the door to serious Victorian-era diseases like scurvy.

title.children: Risk of scurvy, rickets rising amid food affordability crisis, researchers warn

image.altText: The smoking wreckage of a jet with firefighters standing around it

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin takes security seriously, using fake names and body doubles to make himself difficult to trace — it's one of the reasons these experts are sceptical about reports of his death.

title.children: Fake names and body doubles: Why there could be more to the crash that 'killed' Yevgeny Prigozhin

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price looking to the left during a nationals press conference

items.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has implied the government gave unequal treatment to the Yes and No campaigns by "fumbling" the latter's DGR status. Is that correct?

title.children: CheckMate: Did Labor treat the No campaign differently on its tax status?

image.altText: Cleared rainforest

items.synopsis: Millions of tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions are being wiped from company ledgers based on offsets generated from flawed forest conservation schemes, a new study has found.

title.children: Businesses use carbon credits to offset their emissions. A new study finds some aren't offsetting anything at all

image.altText: A man and a woman holding a portrait of their son in his bedroom.

items.synopsis: Rules about who can access posthumous sperm retrieval are ethically complex. It doesn't help that, across Australia, they're also inconsistent.

title.children: These Israeli parents want to use their dead son's sperm to make a grandchild. Could it happen here?

image.altText: man with tattoos on neck in black shirt looks seriously at camera

items.synopsis: He may look like he's fully recovered from a serious car crash but, a year on, Cooper Maher is still silently suffering the impacts of a brain injury.

title.children: Cooper was thrown from a car in a horrific crash. He now suffers an invisible disability

image.altText: A woman wearing a white collared waistcoat sits in an auditorium crowd

items.synopsis: Yang Huiyan is the mysterious majority stakeholder of a sprawling real estate empire in China, but in a stunning reversal of fortune triggered by the country's ongoing property market woes, she is now locked in a desperate battle to prevent its collapse.

title.children: One of China's richest women is an elusive billionaire heiress. Her fortune was just cut in half

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

items.synopsis: The government is failing to convincingly explain the "unusual" decision to not let Qatar Airways expand in Australia at the same time that Treasurer Jim Chalmers is launching a review into competition policy, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The case for more flights seems open and shut. The Albanese government has questions to answer

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

items.synopsis: They may not have won their home Women's World Cup, but in performing the way they did, the Matildas have achieved something far greater than silverware.

title.children: 'I told you so': Matildas' World Cup heroics have won Australian football's biggest fight

image.altText: Old People's Home for 4 Year Olds

items.synopsis: The latest Intergenerational Report predicts we will live longer, we'll be more highly skilled, and we'll have to live under hotter temperatures. Here's what this could mean for our future.

title.children: These six charts show what Australia could look like in 40 years

image.altText: a composite image of the outdoor of two major retail outlets

items.synopsis: A highly anticipated speech by the US Federal Reserve chairman on the state of the US economy has global markets on edge after sending Wall Street lower, while Wesfarmers has reported a near-5 per cent rise in profits. Follow live.

title.children: Bunnings, Kmart boost profits for Wesfarmers, markets 'twitchy' ahead of US Federal Reserve speech, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has opened 1.2% lower this morning, down to 7,094 points as of 10:20am AEST. (For live figures, head to the top of the blog.) All sectors are in the red, with technology down 2%, while industrials fell by 1.9% and basic materials down 1.7%. Real estate is down by 1.7%, while energy is down 1.6%. As for the top movers, they are few and far between right now: Lovisa +4% Wesfarmers +2% Qube Holdings +0.9% Amcor +0.7% Medibank Private +0.6% At the other end though, the bottom five are solidly in negative territory: Pilbara Minerals -6.7% WiseTech Global -5.5% Whitehaven Coal -5.2% Syrah Resources -5.1% GUD Holdings -5.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dragged into the red by miners at the open

children.content: (For live figures, head to the top of the blog.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's head back to the US briefly, where shares in Disney fell by 3.9% at the close of trade overnight, reaching their lowest level in nearly nine years. Disney stockholders have been scrutinising CEO Bob Iger's plans to turn around the entertainment giant, which announced price hikes to its streaming services, more ads, and significant cost cuts to try to boost its business. Investor sentiment led traders towards bearish bets with put options guarding against the stock slipping below $US80 between mid-September and mid-October. The put option gives traders the right to sell shares at a fixed price in the future. Disney was also dragged lower thanks to the weakness in the broader market, with investors increasingly cautious ahead of the Fed chair's speech. Iger has been up front about the entertainment company facing a "challenging environment" in the near term. Disney's stock closed at $US82.47 — the lowest price since October 16, 2014.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney shares fall to lowest level since October 2014

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has launched civil proceedings against Insurance Australia Group (IAG) for allegedly misleading home insurance customers on pricing discounts. The Federal Court proceedings have been launched against IAG's subsidiaries of Insurance Australia Limited (IAL) and Insurance Manufacturers of Australia (IMA). ASIC claims the insurers were misleading in encouraging loyalty discounts to entice customers to renew their home insurance policies, "as loyal customers may have had their premiums increased before the discounts were applied". IAL and IMA renewed more than 1 million home insurance policies, involving the SGIO, SGIC and RACV brands. "We allege that IAG subsidiaries, IAL and IMA, misled their customers about the extent of the discounts they would receive," ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court said. "The way they operated their pricing algorithm meant that some longer term or more loyal customers were allocated, or may have been allocated, higher premiums before the promised discounts were applied. "There is a risk that loyal customers, having been promised a discount, were persuaded to stay with these companies, and in doing so lost their opportunity to shop around for a better price. " ASIC also alleges between August 25, 2017 and August 24, 2023 : IAL made statements about its SGIO and SGIC branded home insurance policies on websites and in other documents that SGIO and SGIC customers would receive a 'Loyalty Discount' IMA made statements about RACV branded home insurance policies on websites and other documents that RACV customers would receive a 'Years of Membership Discount' and/or a 'Multi-Policy Discount', and IAG’s pricing algorithm operated inconsistently with their discount promises and therefore IAG failed to operate efficiently, honestly and fairly. The ABC has contacted IAG for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC sues IAG for misleading customers over home insurance discounts

image.altText: Six passports with details blurred out sitting open on a table.

items.synopsis: The 10 foreigners Singapore police arrested last week in a massive anti-money-laundering operation were citizens of countries including China, Vanuatu, Cyprus, Türkiye and Cambodia. But it's since emerged they were all originally from the same place.

title.children: 'Golden passports': Where did the suspects in Singapore's new billion-dollar money laundering case come from?

image.altText: A female tick biting the skin of a human.

items.synopsis: With ticks thriving after La Niña, more people are expected to be bitten by the parasites, and that could lead to an increase in cases of a potentially life-threatening meat allergy.

title.children: After three wet summers, these tiny creatures are booming. They could make you allergic to red meat

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Three years ago, Qantas A380 planes were gathering dust with the national carrier on the brink of bankruptcy. Today, the airline has unveiled a record profit of $2.47 billion before tax, fuelled by sky-high demand for domestic and international travel.

title.children: 'What money do we pay back exactly?' Qantas CEO Alan Joyce rules out paying back COVID 'bailout'

image.altText: Two people stand in the front yard of a sandbagged home surrounded by floodwater.

items.synopsis: Echuca residents say Victoria's emergency apps need to be updated as the community continues to struggle after last year's disaster.

title.children: Little to no warning ahead of flood that killed 3,500 head of livestock, inquiry hears

image.altText: Michelle Vearing stands hold onto a wire fence in front of Lake Wyangan in Grifftih.

items.synopsis: Cases of motor neurone disease have surged by more than 250 per cent in the past 30 years, and advocates are calling for more research funding to find out why.

title.children: Michelle will not visit a lake where she once spent every weekend, as fears grow it could be leading to a cluster of MND

image.altText: Ajla Tomljanović smiles and looks off to one side

items.synopsis: After a nine-month lay-off caused by injury, Ajla Tomljanović will hit the courts in the first round of the US Open next week, while Alex de Minaur faces a qualifier to kick off his New York campaign.

title.children: Tomljanović to make long-awaited return at US Open

image.altText: a whale breaching in an ocean

items.synopsis: There are concerns about a proposed renewable energy zone off the coast of Victoria and South Australia, which overlaps with the habitats of the southern right and blue whales.

title.children: Risk to endangered whales from offshore wind farms largely unknown, researchers say

image.altText: The leaders of Brazil, China, South Africa and India and Russia's foreign minister hold hands as they pose for a photo.

items.synopsis: Iran, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Argentina, Egypt and Ethiopia are set to join the group next year, potentially bringing three of the biggest oil producers into a bloc China and Russia have been keen to expand to raise their geopolitical influence.

title.children: Six more countries set to join China and Russia in the BRICS economic bloc

image.altText: merino sheep graze on button grass plains with snow covered mountains in the background

items.synopsis: New Zealand is known for its jaw-dropping scenery, first-class food and wine, and sheep — lots of them. But their flock is now a third of what it was 40 years ago, and Aussies are stepping in with plenty of merino wool to sell.

title.children: New Zealand famously has more sheep than people. So why are we shipping our wool to them?

image.altText: a young person from Wear it Purple at this year's Sydney Gay and Lesbian mardi gras

items.synopsis: When Wear it Purple day was founded in 2010, LGBTQIA+ youth were experiencing high rates of discrimination, mental ill health, and homelessness. I wanted to help put a stop to that, writes Katherine Hudson.

title.children: Wear it Purple day started because LGBTQIA+ young people were in crisis. It has changed so much

image.altText: A black and white photo of a man sitting in water under an old hang glider.

items.synopsis: When John Dickenson's unique design for a hang-glider first took flight over the Clarence River in 1963, it revolutionised aviation. Now, the 89-year-old's life and legacy is being commemorated.

title.children: 'Icarus's dream': Hang-gliding community bids farewell to the sport's founding father

image.altText: A centrifuge with a launch spout against a morning sky, clouds pink with sunrise.

items.synopsis: Spinlaunch is looking at several sites around the globe, including two on the south coast of Western Australia, to build its orbital accelerator.

title.children: US spaceflight company considering Australia for space slingshot to catapult rockets into orbit

image.altText: The exterior sign of the Gillen Club, with a slogan reading 'your club, your community'

items.synopsis: A court has heard a woman was ejected from an Alice Springs social club in the hours before her partner murdered her, even though she had expressed concerns about him to staff, and he was being publicly threatening towards her.

title.children: Murdered woman ejected from club after asking aggressive partner to be removed, inquest hears

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: The Australian Electoral Commission has said ticks would likely be counted as Yes votes, while a cross would likely not be counted, a decision that has attracted the ire of the federal Coalition.

title.children: 'Just stinks': Dutton to complain to AEC about tick and cross Voice referendum voting

image.altText: Palm trees and white sand with blue water

items.synopsis: The well-known tourist destination of South Molle island could soon have a new owner as it becomes the latest Great Barrier Reef island to come up for sale after Lindeman Island, Hook Island, Dunk Island and Long Island.

title.children: Ever wanted to buy a Whitsunday island? This former resort has hit the market

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Luis Rubiales created controversy following Spain's 1-0 win over England in the final, when he kissed Jenni Hermoso as she received her winner's medal.

title.children: FIFA opens disciplinary proceedings over World Cup podium kiss
